greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of nonnegative solutions to the equation x^4 + y^4 = n.
comment: The first n with a(n) > 1 is 635318657 = 41 * 113 * 241 * 569, with a(635318657) = 2. Izadi, Khoshnam, & Nabardi show that for any n with a(n) > 1, the elliptic curve y^2 = x^3 - nx has rank at least 3. According to gp, y^2 = x^3 - 635318657x has analytic rank 4 (and first nonzero derivative around 35741.7839). - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jan 12 2017
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16561
F. A. Izadi, F. Khoshnam, K. Nabardi, Sums of two biquadrates and elliptic curves of rank ≥4 (2012). arXiv:1202.5676 [math.NT], 2012.
F. A. Izadi, F. Khoshnam, K. Nabardi, Sums of two biquadrates and elliptic curves of rank ≥ 4, Math. J. Okayama Univ. 56 (2014), 51-63.
mathematica: Reap[For[n = 1, n <= 1000, n++, r = Reduce[0 <= x <= y && x^4 + y^4 == n, {x, y}, Integers]; sols = Which[r === False, 0, r[[0]] == And, 1, r[[0]] == Or, Length[r], True, Print[n, " ", r]]; If[sols != 0, Print[n, " ", sols, " ", r]]; Sow[sols]]][[2, 1]] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 22 2019 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(t=thue(thueinit('x^4+1,1),n)); sum(i=1,#t, t[i][1]>=0 && t[i][2]>=t[i][1]) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jan 12 2017
(PARI) first(n)=my(T=thueinit('x^4+1,1),v=vector(n),t); for(k=1,n, t=thue(T,k); v[k]=sum(i=1,#t, t[i][1]>=0 && t[i][2]>=t[i][1])); v \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jan 12 2017
results.author: _V. Raman_, Sep 03 2012
